article_title: 50 years on: Wilderness Act preserves Yuma-area refuges
article_text:
Kofa National Wildlife Refuge Signs along the dirt road between U.S. 95 and the Palm Canyon parking area are clear reminders that the canyon is on the Kofa National Wildlife Refuge. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife service is celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Wilderness Act of 1964, which protects millions of acres of federal land including the Kofa National Wildlife Refuge and Imperial National Wildlife Refuge, both located north of Yuma. Buy this photo

Imperial National Wildlife Refuge A boat pulls a skier on the Colorado River inside the Imperial National Wildlife Refuge. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife service is celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Wilderness Act of 1964, which protects millions of acres of federal land including the Kofa National Wildlife Refuge and Imperial National Wildlife Refuge, both located north of Yuma. Buy this photo

Palm Canyon Visitors on bicycles to Palm Canyon on the Kofa National Wildlife Refuge check out informative signs at the base of the canyon before undertaking the hike. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife service is celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Wilderness Act of 1964, which protects millions of acres of federal land including the Kofa National Wildlife Refuge and Imperial National Wildlife Refuge, both located north of Yuma. Buy this photo

og.description: Fifty years on, the Wilderness Act of 1964 continues to protect more than 700,000 acres of pristine wilderness surrounding the Yuma area.
